header.title: Company of Prophets: African American Psychics, Healers & Visionaries

central_thesis: The book documents and analyzes the diverse expressions of intuitivity, psychic abilities, and spiritual practices among U.S.-born African Americans, highlighting their unique spiritual heritage, challenges, and contributions to healing and visionary traditions, often drawing parallels to ancient African and New Age philosophies. It aims to acknowledge and validate these experiences which have historically been overlooked.

structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the early psychic experiences of African American children, detailing how they manifested gifts such as precognition, astral projection, clairvoyance, and healing, often facing fear, isolation, or rejection from adults. It showcases individuals like Jenny Benson Vaughn, Henry Rucker, and Dorothy Hall who developed and, in some cases, repressed or later embraced their unique abilities, emphasizing the innate nature of these gifts.

Focuses on mediumship within the African American community, defining its forms from traditional spirit communication to channeling extradimensional entities. It features profiles of prominent mediums like Louise Washington, Mother Susie Booth, and Nellye Mae Taylor, detailing their methods, spirit guides, and experiences with physical phenomena like apportation and psychic healing, often within a Spiritualist or African spiritual context.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Three: Ascetics, Ecstatics, and Seekers
structure_content.summary: This section examines individuals who pursue spiritual understanding through asceticism, ecstatic experiences, and seeking higher consciousness. It includes figures like Master Walter Thomas, Amanda Smith, William Grant Still, and Harriet Tubman, whose spiritual journeys involved divine revelations, dreams, visions, and a profound connection to God that guided their lives and actions, often in service to others.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Four: And Some Are Old Souls
structure_content.summary: Explores the concept of reincarnation and past life memories within the experiences of African American psychics. It discusses various ways these memories manifest—dreams, visions, sudden insight, deja vu, spiritual discipline, soul-mate meetings, past life regression therapy, and readings. Individuals such as Richmond Barthe, London Wildwind, and June Gatlin share their recollections and insights into former existences and their impact on current life purpose.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Five: Gifted in Physical Healing
structure_content.summary: Details the practices of physical healing among African American psychics and healers, emphasizing laying on of hands, prayer, and other spiritual intercessions. It features practitioners like Peter Brown, James Moye (a Yoruban priest), June Gatlin, and Rebecca Cox Jackson, who demonstrate abilities to diagnose illnesses, facilitate physical changes, and cure ailments, often by working with divine energy or spirit guides.

This chapter addresses the phenomenon of discarnate negative spirits and the methods used by psychics to dispel their harmful influences. It describes how individuals like Hayward Coleman, Henry Rucker, and Mother Estelle Ellerbee identify and confront these entities, using spiritual power, prayer, and specific techniques to protect individuals and cleanse spaces from obsession and negative energy.

Explores experiences of out-of-body travel and extraphysical dimensions. Individuals such as Luisah Teish, Clarence Ellerbee, and Hayward Coleman recount their journeys beyond the physical body, describing how these experiences offer insights into spiritual realities, facilitate healing, and are sometimes a natural, uncontrolled phenomenon from childhood.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Eight: By Way of Rites
structure_content.summary: Examines the use of ceremonies, symbols, and divinatory tools to enhance spiritual, emotional, and physical well-being. It details the practices of figures like Henry Rucker (Tarot, palmistry), Pepe Washington (African cowrie shells, telepathy), Mary Bivens (rituals, herbs), and Lloyd Strayhorn (numerology, astrology), emphasizing the philosophical and spiritual aspects behind these methods rather than mere fortune-telling.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Nine: Legacy of Second Sight
structure_content.summary: Investigates the inheritance of psychic gifts within families, often indicated by physical natal signs like 'the veil' or 'caul'. It highlights how these abilities are passed down through generations, shaping family dynamics and individual paths. Examples include Howard Thurman, Fannie Bell Chapman, and Delilah Grayer, illustrating the blend of genetic predisposition and spiritual legacy.

This concluding chapter synthesizes the various manifestations of spirit and psychism, often focusing on psychics who also serve as teachers and community leaders. It reinforces themes of spiritual connection, purpose, and the role of these gifts in individual and collective empowerment, drawing on the wisdom shared by many of the figures profiled throughout the book to illustrate the breadth of African American spiritual traditions.

key_concepts.definition: A broad term encompassing extrasensory perception, spiritual awareness, and psychic ability, often presented as an innate capacity within African American culture.

The sensitivity to spirit world vibrations, allowing intelligences from that realm to convey messages and manifest phenomena, including communication from deceased individuals and extradimensional entities (channeling).

The ability to effect physical, emotional, and spiritual changes in others, often through laying on of hands, prayer, visualization, energy alignment, and the guidance of spiritual entities, sometimes involving the absorption and release of negative energies.

The experience of the consciousness or 'astral body' separating from the physical body and traveling in extraphysical dimensions or to distant locations, sometimes spontaneously or through specific techniques.

Innate psychic gifts, often indicated by specific physical natal signs such as being born with a 'veil' (caul) over the head or face, which are associated with the ability to see spirits and prophesy. 'Nine heads' is another term used to describe such inherent abilities.

Discarnate or extradimensional intelligences that provide guidance, protection, and instruction to psychics and healers. In some African traditions, these are referred to as Orisha, divine beings who assist humans and are often associated with natural elements and specific attributes.

Traditional African American healers and practitioners who use herbs, rituals, and spiritual knowledge to diagnose, heal, and address spiritual and physical problems, often with an emphasis on controlling spirits or working with nature's forces.

The ability to gain information (mental pictures, vibrations) about a person or event by touching an object associated with them, often used in readings to discern current circumstances or past lives.

A religious movement (often within the African American context, such as the National Colored Spiritualist Association) affirming communication with the deceased, the continuity of individual identity after death, and the scientific proof of such phenomena through mediumship.

The concept, often derived from Eastern or New Age metaphysics, that an individual soul experiences multiple lifetimes, with present experiences and challenges often stemming from actions and lessons in previous incarnations ('old souls').

practical_system.description: The book details a multifaceted practical system rooted in innate psychic abilities, ancestral spiritual wisdom, and divine guidance. It emphasizes personal spiritual development (e.g., meditation, self-awareness) combined with specific operative techniques. The core philosophy centers on acknowledging and utilizing inherent spiritual gifts for healing, guidance, and community upliftment, often in defiance of societal norms or traditional religious dogmas.
tools: Tarot cards and playing cards for divination and self-knowledge.
Crystal balls and natural crystals for scrying and receiving images.
I Ching cubes and Astro Stones as divination tools.
African cowrie shells, tea leaves, sand, runes for readings.
Herbs and roots for healing remedies (often specified by spirit guides).
Candles and incense for setting spiritual atmosphere and focus.
Music (piano, guitar, tambourines) and singing as channels for spiritual energy.
Mirrors (though not explicitly detailed, the mention of 'magic mirrors' by Randolph hints at their use in divination).
The Bible, used as a sacred text for guidance, healing, and a source of spiritual wisdom.
rituals: Prayer and focused intention for healing and guidance.
Laying on of hands for physical and spiritual healing.
Cleansing baths using specific herbs and water, often with communal participation.
Communing with spirit guides and ancestors for instruction and support.
Vibrational work through singing (gospel), chanting, and dance to align energies.
Dreamwork for prophetic insight, problem-solving, and past life understanding.
Meditation and visualization techniques for self-attunement, energy manipulation, and conscious development of psychic faculties.
Exorcism/dispelling negative spirits through direct command ('In the name of Jesus, come out!'), prayer, and energy work.
Rituals involving specific objects (e.g., anointing with oil, using the Bible, working with altars) for spiritual purposes.

The doctrine of reincarnation is a non-Western way in which the spiritual issues of the immortality of the soul, individual spiritual progress, and personal salvation are addressed. According to basic reincarnation theory, many lifetimes are lived by the individual soul in unending succession. Once a cycle of birth-through-death is completed, the soul assumes another body, most often close to the time of birth. With that physical form begins yet another period of existence. But periods of rest between incarnations also occur.

"I am who I am. I was before I came to this body.' Sculptor Richmond Barthe perceives among his former incarnations those lifetimes he spent as an artist. "The first time I tried portrait sculpture instead of painting, it was classic. You don't start with classic. You have to work up to classic. I have never done anything that was amateurish or primitive. My work has always been classic. And that convinces me that what mediums have said to me is true. Three of them told me the same thing. That I was a very old soul. They told me the different countries I have lived in."

"I had a dream that my mother surprised me at Christmas with a suit I really wanted. She didn't put it under the tree until later on Christmas Day. And that happened in reality! In the dream I wore the suit to school and a string was hanging down. I pulled the string and the suit fell apart. I totally forgot about the dream and wore the outfit to school. With her gifted daughter, Bakara Oni, Delilah Grayer now lives in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

"My mother told me I was born with the veil,' states June Gatlin, spiritual healer, singer, and poet, who grew up on Moon Street in Akron, Ohio. From Chicago astrologer James Black she learned that at the time of her birth all the ancient planets were in their signs of rulership. He used the Bible to do her chart the ancient way, and conveyed to her she held the key to the Lion of Judah. "He said he had never seen a chart like mine in his seventy years!"

The presence of certain body markings, delivery conditions, or planetary signs and changes at the time of birth have been considered, in cultures around the world and down the ages, as physical indications that the newborn child has entered life with unusual powers. The veil, or the caul, is probably the best known of the physical natal signs. It is a strong thin tissue which on occasion completely caps a baby's head or face at birth. The medical term is "amnion," that inmost membrane filled with fluid which surrounds the fetus before birth. Also called the "bag of waters." Sometimes a child is born totally enclosed in the unbroken bag. Often associated with the veil are the abilities to see spirits and to prophesy. Expressions such as "two-headed" and "nine-headed" refer to individuals possessing psychic gifts.

The influence of African religion which James Moye observed in his childhood church gives evidence to how spiritual legacy passes from ancestors to descendants. Kathleen Carter, Alfred Ligon, Luisah Teish, and Howard Thurman have similar perceptions. By way of the slaves from Africa, as early as the 1600s, ancient religious and mystical beliefs, practices, and observances of Africa were carried to the New World. The spiritual heritage of African Americans is in this way founded in the Group Spirit of ancestors whose religious precepts predate Western ones. Some metaphysicians see the roots of the planet's religions as beginning in Africa and India. African Americans thus reflect, to varying degrees in their beliefs and practices, the earliest religious and spiritual heritages of Earth's prerecorded history.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book holds significant relevance within Western Esotericism and Occultism by documenting diverse psychic and spiritual phenomena through the lens of African American experiences. It challenges Eurocentric biases in esoteric studies by presenting a rich tradition of indigenous spiritual practices, mediumship, healing, and visionary states deeply rooted in African heritage. The text's focus on personal narratives provides a unique phenomenological insight into operative magic and spiritual work, contextualizing practices often marginalized or misunderstood within broader occult discourse. It connects modern psychic abilities to ancestral lineages, ancient African religions (like Yoruba Orisha traditions), and foundational spiritual principles, demonstrating a continuity of magical thought and practice that predates many Western esoteric systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes academics in religious studies, sociology, anthropology, and African American studies interested in non-mainstream spirituality; practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic seeking to broaden their understanding of diverse spiritual traditions; individuals exploring personal psychic development, healing, and ancestral connections; and those interested in the historical and cultural expressions of spirituality within the African American community.
